t: Psalm 78
A maskil of Asaph.
My*pn people, hear my teaching; listen*ld to the words of my mouth.
I*ln will open my mouth with a parable; I*ld will utter hidden things, things from of old—
things*ln we have heard and known, things*ld our ancestors have told us.
We*ln will not hide them from their descendants; we*ld will tell the next generation the*ln praiseworthy deeds of the Lord,*s his*ld power, and the wonders he has done.
He*ln decreed statutes for Jacob and*ld established the law in Israel, which*ln he commanded our ancestors to*ld teach their children,
so*ln the next generation would know them, even*ld the children yet to be born, and*ld they in turn would tell their children.
Then*ln they would put their trust in God and*ld would not forget his deeds but*ld would keep his commands.
They*ln would not be like their ancestors— a*ld stubborn and rebellious generation, whose*ln hearts were not loyal to God, whose*ld spirits were not faithful to him.
The*pn men of Ephraim, though armed with bows, turned*ld back on the day of battle;
they*ln did not keep God’s covenant and*ld refused to live by his law.
They*ln forgot what he had done, the*ld wonders he had shown them.
He*ln did miracles in the sight of their ancestors in*ld the land of Egypt, in the region of Zoan.
He*ln divided the sea and led them through; he*ld made the water stand up like a wall.
He*ln guided them with the cloud by day and*ld with light from the fire all night.
He*ln split the rocks in the wilderness and*ld gave them water as abundant as the seas;
he*ln brought streams out of a rocky crag and*ld made water flow down like rivers.
But*pn they continued to sin against him, rebelling*ld in the wilderness against the Most High.
They*ln willfully put God to the test by*ld demanding the food they craved.
They*ln spoke against God; they*ld said, “Can God really spread*ld a table in the wilderness?
True,*ln he struck the rock, and*ld water gushed out, streams*ld flowed abundantly, but*ln can he also give us bread? Can*ld he supply meat for his people?”
When*ln the Lord*s heard them, he was furious; his*ld fire broke out against Jacob, and*ld his wrath rose against Israel,
for*ln they did not believe in God or*ld trust in his deliverance.
Yet*ln he gave a command to the skies above and*ld opened the doors of the heavens;
he*ln rained down manna for the people to eat, he*ld gave them the grain of heaven.
Human*ln beings ate the bread of angels; he*ld sent them all the food they could eat.
He*ln let loose the east wind from the heavens and*ld by his power made the south wind blow.
He*ln rained meat down on them like dust, birds*ld like sand on the seashore.
He*ln made them come down inside their camp, all*ld around their tents.
They*ln ate till they were gorged— he*ld had given them what they craved.
But*ln before they turned from what they craved, even*ld while the food was still in their mouths,
God’s*ln anger rose against them; he*ld put to death the sturdiest among them, cutting*ld down the young men of Israel.
In*pn spite of all this, they kept on sinning; in*ld spite of his wonders, they did not believe.
So*ln he ended their days in futility and*ld their years in terror.
Whenever*ln God slew them, they would seek him; they*ld eagerly turned to him again.
They*ln remembered that God was their Rock, that*ld God Most High was their Redeemer.
But*ln then they would flatter him with their mouths, lying*ld to him with their tongues;
their*ln hearts were not loyal to him, they*ld were not faithful to his covenant.
Yet*ln he was merciful; he*ld forgave their iniquities and*ld did not destroy them. Time*ln after time he restrained his anger and*ld did not stir up his full wrath.
He*ln remembered that they were but flesh, a*ld passing breeze that does not return.
How*pn often they rebelled against him in the wilderness and*ld grieved him in the wasteland!
Again*ln and again they put God to the test; they*ld vexed the Holy One of Israel.
They*ln did not remember his power— the*ld day he redeemed them from the oppressor,
the*ln day he displayed his signs in Egypt, his*ld wonders in the region of Zoan.
He*ln turned their river into blood; they*ld could not drink from their streams.
He*ln sent swarms of flies that devoured them, and*ld frogs that devastated them.
He*ln gave their crops to the grasshopper, their*ld produce to the locust.
He*ln destroyed their vines with hail and*ld their sycamore-figs with sleet.
He*ln gave over their cattle to the hail, their*ld livestock to bolts of lightning.
He*ln unleashed against them his hot anger, his*ld wrath, indignation and hostility— a*ld band of destroying angels.
He*ln prepared a path for his anger; he*ld did not spare them from death but*ld gave them over to the plague.
He*ln struck down all the firstborn of Egypt, the*ld firstfruits of manhood in the tents of Ham.
But*ln he brought his people out like a flock; he*ld led them like sheep through the wilderness.
He*ln guided them safely, so they were unafraid; but*ld the sea engulfed their enemies.
And*ln so he brought them to the border of his holy land, to*ld the hill country his right hand had taken.
He*ln drove out nations before them and*ld allotted their lands to them as an inheritance; he*ld settled the tribes of Israel in their homes.
But*pn they put God to the test and*ld rebelled against the Most High; they*ld did not keep his statutes.
Like*ln their ancestors they were disloyal and faithless, as*ld unreliable as a faulty bow.
They*ln angered him with their high places; they*ld aroused his jealousy with their idols.
When*ln God heard them, he was furious; he*ld rejected Israel completely.
He*ln abandoned the tabernacle of Shiloh, the*ld tent he had set up among humans.
He*ln sent the ark of his might into captivity, his*ld splendor into the hands of the enemy.
He*ln gave his people over to the sword; he*ld was furious with his inheritance.
Fire*ln consumed their young men, and*ld their young women had no wedding songs;
their*ln priests were put to the sword, and*ld their widows could not weep.
Then*pn the Lord awoke as from sleep, as*ld a warrior wakes from the stupor of wine.
He*ln beat back his enemies; he*ld put them to everlasting shame.
Then*ln he rejected the tents of Joseph, he*ld did not choose the tribe of Ephraim;
but*ln he chose the tribe of Judah, Mount*ld Zion, which he loved.
He*ln built his sanctuary like the heights, like*ld the earth that he established forever.
He*ln chose David his servant and*ld took him from the sheep pens;
from*ln tending the sheep he brought him to*ld be the shepherd of his people Jacob, of*ld Israel his inheritance.
And*ln David shepherded them with integrity of heart; with*ld skillful hands he led them.
